awd_titl_txt: NeuroDataRR: Replication of cortical microstructure correlations with face and object recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
Face recognition is an important skill that most people begin to acquire early in life, while other human activities depend on expertise that only some of us learn as adults (e.g., recognizing cars or matching fingerprints). Prior work with a small sample of only men found that it is possible to predict behavioral performance in such tasks based on the thickness of the cortex in a part of the brain that responds preferentially to faces. Importantly, the manner in which face and non-face recognition abilities were predicted by brain structure was different, with individuals with thicker cortex being better at recognizing vehicles than those with thinner cortex, while individuals with thinner cortex performing better in face recognition tasks. In addition, for faces, only the thickness of the deeper, early developing, layers of the cortex predicted performance. This research will test whether these results replicate in a larger sample of men and women. It will investigate how connections between face-selective cortex and other parts of the brain sensitive to  social interactions could help explain how early experience with faces influences the thickness of deep cortical layers. A better understanding of how the structure of the brain relates to visual abilities could extend predictions to a wide range of occupations such as forensics, medical imaging, and homeland security. The work could also transform how we study cortical development in neurological disorders such as Autism Spectrum Disorders. The project will improve participation of underrepresented middle and high school students from Nashville public schools and increase scientific literacy, via the team's contributions to the School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt.

This research seeks to advance our understanding of how the cortical microstructure of visual areas relates to individual differences in visual abilities. Using ultra-high resolution imaging at 7 Tesla and state-of-the-art psychometric measurement of visual abilities, the project will replicate and extend findings relating visual recognition of faces and objects to the laminar structure of cortex in the fusiform face area (FFA). The project will also test for replication of the relation between one's social network size and the size of the amygdala (AMG), and test whether AMG size mediates the correlation between face recognition and the thickness of FFA's deep layers. The work will generalize prior findings with men to a sample of women, expand behavioral testing to new object categories, and compare laminar effects in FFA to those in other visual areas. Studying the neuromarkers of visual abilities can increase our understanding of brain-behavior relationships beyond already successful domains like general intelligence or health-related behaviors.

por.por_cntn:
Our project aimed to replicate and extend previous findings on how the structure of the brain's cortex is related to our ability to recognize faces and objects. By using advanced imaging techniques and comprehensive behavioral tests, we sought to deepen our understanding of these relationships in a larger and more diverse group of participants.

We gathered a robust sample including men and women to replicate and extend previous results. We expanded the battery of behavioral tests to include a wide range of visual recognition tasks and we obtain reliable measurements of the thickness of individual layers in several visual areas simultaneously using high-resolution imaging techniques. This represents a major advance, because our prior methods only allowed us to measure the thickness of layers in a single part of the brain at a time.

Accomplishments:

1. Data Collection: Despite delays caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, we collected data from 128 adults (51 men and 77 women). This sample size allows us to explore the relationship between face and object recognition abilities and the thickness of cortical layers in the brain's ventral temporal cortex, including potential gender differences.

2. Behavioral Testing: Participants completed 14 different behavioral tests, measuring their ability to recognize faces, vehicles, living objects, novel objects, and perceive visual ensembles. This allows us to average scores for different tasks for each category, to better examine brain-behavior relationships across different domains.

3. Imaging: We implemented a new processing pipeline to measure the thickness of different brain layers across multiple regions of interest. This novel approach allowed us to obtain reliable laminar estimates in an expanded field of view, facilitating detailed correlations between brain structure and visual recognition abilities.

Findings:

  1. Behavioral Variability: The expanded behavioral measures allowed robust estimation of individual differences in visual recognition abilities.
  2. Imaging Advancements: We developed methods to obtain reliable laminar thickness measurements in multiple regions simultaneously, overcoming challenges related to the angle of acquisition and resolution (Figure 1).
  3. Relating laminar cortical thickness to behavior: For the first time, we are able to correlate behavioral abilities (for face recognition, car recognition and novel object recognition) to cortical thickness of layers in several areas (instead of only a single area).

Impact:

  • Data Sharing: The data and methodologies developed are publicly available, providing valuable resources for future research.
  • Training and Development: The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students, providing them with hands-on research experience in experimental evolution, bioinformatics, and neuroimaging.
  • Conference Presentations: The results have been presented at various international conferences, enhancing the project's visibility and impact.
  • First journal article: McGugin, R. W., Roche, A., Ma, J., & Gauthier, I. (2024). Challenges in replication: Does amygdala gray matter volume relate to social network size? Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 1-13.

This project has advanced our understanding of how cortical microstructure relates to visual recognition abilities. Because this is an individual differences project, the final results await completion of all brain analyses, which were delayed because of COVID-19, but which we are confident can be completed even though funding has ended. We have developed a robust analysis pipeline such that Vanderbilt students working for research experience can help complete the approximately 800 hours of remaining analyses, ensuring the project's long-term impact. Our findings will have implications for future research in neuroscience and cognitive science. The methodologies and data generated will continue to support ongoing studies in these fields.
